slide.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to move smoothly over a surface while continuing to touch it, or to make something move in this way
slide.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: He opened the oven door and slid the pan of cookies in.
He slid open the door of the glass cabinet.
slide.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to move somewhere quietly and smoothly, or to move something in this way
slide.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Daniel slid out of the room when no one was looking.
She slid into the driver’s seat.
He slid the gun into his pocket.
slide something into/out of etc something
slide.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: if prices, amounts, rates etc slide, they become lower
slide.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Stocks slid a further 3% on the major markets today.
slide.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to gradually become worse, or to begin to have a problem
slide.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: Students’ test scores started to slide in the mid-1990s.
Murphy gradually slid into a pattern of drug abuse.
slide.translation[0].note_box[0].section: slide
to move smoothly over a surface while continuing to touch it
The glass slid off the tray and crashed to the floor.
The kids were having fun sliding around on the polished floor.
slip
to slide a short distance accidentally, and fall or lose your balance slightly
Be careful you don’t slip on the ice.
She slipped and broke her ankle.
skid
to slide sideways or forwards in a way that is difficult to control – used especially about a moving vehicle
He slammed on the brakes and the car skidded to a halt.
Go slowly in wet or icy weather, because it’s easy to skid.
glide
to move smoothly and quietly across water or a smooth surface, especially in a graceful way
A swan was gliding across the lake.
The ship glided into port.
slither
to slide in an awkward way, for example on a rough or muddy surface. Also used to describe the movement of a snake as it goes from side to side along the ground
Tom slithered down the bank into the water.
The snake slithered away and disappeared under a rock.
slide.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: a large structure with steps leading to the top of a long sloping surface that children can slide down
slide.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: a decrease in prices, amounts etc
slide.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: the current slide in house prices
The company’s shares were on the slide again yesterday, down 7p at 339p.
slide.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: a small piece of film in a frame that you shine a light through to show a picture on a screen or wall
slide.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: a situation in which something gradually gets worse, or someone develops a problem
slide.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: School administrators were unable to explain the slide in student performance.
slide.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: a small piece of thin glass used for holding something that you want to look at under a microscope
slide.translation[1].definitions[5].defi: a sliding part of a machine or musical instrument, such as the U-shaped tube of a trombone
slide.translation[1].definitions[6].defi: a sliding movement across a surface
slide.translation[1].definitions[6].exam: The car went into a slide.
slide.translation[1].definitions[7].defi: a sudden fall of earth, stones, snow etc down a slope
slide.translation[1].definitions[8].defi: a small metal or plastic object that holds your hair in place
slide.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: to gradually become lower or less
slide.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: Some dealers continued to buy silver as the price slid.
The new model didn’t stop their share of the U.S. car market from sliding.
